I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This capacity development technical assistance (TA) aims to address common public 
health and social problems encountered by urban communities in Indonesia and the Philippines 
that are affected by toxic industrial pollution from informal backyard and formal micro, small, and 
medium-sized industries. This support is in line with the fourth pillar of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) regional cooperation strategy, namely the provision of regional public goods.1  The 
TA is also consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) for Indonesia for 2012–
2014.2 The second pillar of this CPS calls for support for environmental sustainability and 
climate change mitigation and adaptation, including the management of river basins to improve 
water quality and mitigate and manage floods. The TA also aligns with ADB’s CPS for the 
Philippines  for  2011–2016.  The  CPS  seeks  to  reduce  environmental  degradation  and 
vulnerability  to  climate  change  and  disasters  by  helping  the  government  gain  access  to 
concessionary resources made available for greenhouse gas mitigation in the land use sectors 
at the global level; working with government and the private sector on possible public–private 
partnership solutions; and improving sustainable environmental infrastructure in urban areas.3  
 
2.  Indonesia’s  Ministry  of  Environment  (MOE)  and  the  Philippines’  Department  of 
Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), through letters of request dated 17 December 
2012  and  7  January  2013,  asked  ADB  for  assistance  from  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty 
Reduction (JFPR) to help pilot activities aimed at mitigating the industrial pollution and the 
resulting social and public health impacts caused by gold smelters, tanneries, and discarded 
lead batteries in certain urban areas. An ADB reconnaissance mission from 20 February to 8 
March 2013, involved discussions with representatives and officials from the embassies of 
Japan, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency offices in Jakarta and Manila; the MOE 
and the State Ministry of National Development Planning in Jakarta; the DENR and the National 
Economic and Development Authority in Manila; and the stakeholders from the proposed project 
sites.  The  stakeholders  included  nongovernment  organizations  and  community  and  local 
government representatives. All the government agencies and organizations the mission met 
expressed  full  support  for  the  project,  including  its  intended  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference,  and 
concurred with the project design. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The interventions and environmental legislation of the governments of Indonesia and the 
Philippines aimed at reducing industrial pollution have focused almost exclusively on heavy 
industries in the formal sector. These activities have overlooked the widespread micro, small, 
and medium-sized industries that operate under little or no pollution controls in the two countries. 
The negative effects of the pollution these enterprises—and informal backyard industries in 
particular—impose  on  poor  and  marginalized  populations  living  in  high-density  areas,  on 
riverbanks, and in other residential areas near industrial zones have therefore escaped official 
response.  Operating  with  no  oversight  and  with  insufficient  knowledge  and  awareness  of 
environmental protection, these industries contaminate air, soil, and ground and surface water 
sources. This in turn affects the health of their workers, people in the immediate neighborhood, 
and downstream river network communities that often depend on the land and water resources 
being polluted for their domestic water and such livelihood and subsistence activities as fish 
                                                
1  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.  
2  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Indonesia, 2012–2014. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Philippines, 2011–2016. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 June 2013.

2   
farming. Soil contamination produced by these industries damages agriculture production in 
suburban areas. Crops absorb the toxins, thereby contaminating food for human consumption. 
Air pollution from these industries reduces air quality and causes respiratory-related diseases in 
surrounding  communities.  Urban  communities  are  affected  by  both  direct  exposure  to  the 
pollutants and bioaccumulation through the food chain.  
 
4.  Pollution in 70% of Asia’s cities exceeds the levels recommended by the World Health 
Organization and, by one account, has caused 800,000 premature deaths in the region in 
2005.5 Contamination of the environment by hazardous waste is a growing issue for low- and 
middle-income countries. An analysis of 164 contaminated sites between 2010 and 2011 in 
Indonesia and the Philippines estimated that the impact of diseases caused by toxic exposure is 
similar to that of malaria. The analysis reported that 161,582 (about three for every 1,000) 
children in these countries suffered from degraded mental and physical functions due to lead 
exposure from waste. Health impacts of toxic waste contamination hinder inclusive development 
by impairing the mental and psychomotor functioning of the poor and excluded in affected 
areas.6 Overall, the pollution of air, water, and soil reduces the productivity of communities by 
negatively affecting their health, harvests, and catch, as well as the intellectual capacity of their 
populations and the socioeconomic functions necessary for their residents to provide for their 
needs.  
 
5.  Lead and other heavy metal pollution that results from inadequately controlled formal 
and  informal  sector  battery  breaking,  recycling,  smelting,  and  related  activities  is  a  major 
environmental threat in urban areas throughout Indonesia. The recycling and smelting industry 
is poorly regulated and many operations are conducted in the open air in densely populated 
urban areas with few, if any pollution controls. In 2001, the MOE, along with the United States 
Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Center for Disease Control, found that 
35% of school children tested in Jakarta had lead concentrations in their blood that were above 
accepted standards. A 2007 study found similar results in four other cities (32% in Bandung,   
53% in Makassar, 40% in Palembang, and 18% in Surabaya). Lead contamination has caused 
significant health problems for the smelting plant workers and individuals from surrounding 
communities, often manifesting as nerve and mental function abnormalities. In the Philippines, 
the river system running through the three municipalities of Marilao, Meycauayan, and Obando 
on northern boundary of Metro Manila, poses a major pollution problem. The system in these 
municipalities is a major catchment for flows through Metro Manila that discharge into Manila 
Bay. This river system is heavily contaminated by heavy metals, untreated wastewater, oil and 
chemical discharges from industrial establishments, which threaten the health and livelihoods of 
both urban and rural communities.  
 
6.  Such pollution creates gender issues.  Women are affected through the disruption it 
causes in their daily routines or to their households budgets by compelling them to fetch clean 
water from areas far from their houses or to buy it from peddlers. Some of the workers in 
informal  smelting  plants  who  are  in  danger  of  suffering  pollution-induced  nerve  and  brain 
dysfunction are female.  
 
7.  Inclusive growth cannot be achieved if the resources that communities depend on are 
damaged by pollution. The TA activities to initiate environmental management measures will 
therefore support inclusive growth in these pollution-afflicted areas.  
                                                
5  ADB. 2006. Urban Air Quality Management: Summary of Country/City Synthesis Reports Across Asia. Manila.     
6   Global Alliance on Health and Pollution. 2013. The Poisoned Poor: Toxic Chemicals Exposures in Low and Middle-
Income Countries. New York: Blacksmith Institute.

3 
8.  This TA will help concerned government agencies and communities improve the quality 
of life of affected communities in the two countries, as well as the operations of micro, small, 
and  medium-sized  formal  and  informal  sector  industries  in  urban  areas.  The  TA  will  also 
address climate change issues by helping to develop antipollution devices for smoke emissions 
from legal, small-scale smelting operations. If use of these devices is scaled up to cover a wider 
geographic  area,  this  will  reduce the  amount of  greenhouse gas  emissions  released from 
smelting operations. The areas where smelting industries are located are vulnerable to the 
pollution  effects  of  climate  change  as  frequent  rains  could  increase  surface  run-offs  of 
contaminated soil into the river systems. The TA will build on the outputs and studies of ADB TA 
that supported the implementation of the Global Inventory Project7 in Asia and the Pacific,8 and 
analyzed sites suspected to have been contaminated in Indonesia and the Philippines. These 
included the sites nominated for this project.9 The TA revealed that the top contaminants in 
urban areas and in the sites analyzed were produced by battery recycling, smelting, and leather 
tanning. These activities are often done in micro, small, and medium-sized establishments that 
are located within or adjacent to densely populated areas and discharge untreated effluents into 
surrounding bodies of water and on agricultural lands. The TA project will also address the 
lessons learned from the  ADB Metro Manila Air Quality Improvement Sector Development 
Program.10 The program eliminated lead concentrations from the Metro Manila air shed, but 
program completion report noted several shortcomings and loopholes in its design (footnote 10). 
The program neglected economic and social dimensions of air quality management and the 
sustainability  of  capacity-building  initiatives,  pursued  complex  objectives  that  were 
overambitious, and resulted in a mismatch between the program expectations and the results 
the executing and implementing agencies anticipated and had the capacity to deliver.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  expected  impact  will  be  improved  environmental  management  and  community 
development capacities in selected locations in Indonesia and the Philippines. The outcome will 
be  awareness  and  increased knowledge  of and  institutional  capacities  on  how  to mitigate 
hazardous waste contamination created in pilot locations and among affected stakeholders.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The  TA  is  expected  to  bring  about  (i)  increased  awareness  within  governments, 
communities, and industries of the impact of toxic industrial pollution and of the need for and 
dependence on protecting available land and water resources; (ii) strengthened capacity of 
governments  and  other  stakeholders  on  integrating  environmental management  with  urban 
development; and (iii) sustainable strategies and measures, which are to be demonstrated 
through pilot activities in the project areas, to address the environmental and social issues 
brought about by toxic industrial pollution and its effects on these communities. It is assumed 
that mitigating environmental impacts of industrial waste pollution and contamination will remain

a high priority of the government and that communities will regard it as an urgent issue and 
concern. However, there is also a possibility of reluctance from communities to adopt proposed 
community interventions such as alternative livelihoods to do away with traditional smelting as 
vocation, or that governments and communities may lack the sustained commitment to continue 
the TA activities after the project ends. ADB has limited experience in dealing with these 
environmental  issues.  That  is  why  the  services  of  highly  competent  consultants  with  vast 
experience on industrial pollution mitigation will be engaged for the TA.   
   
11.  Output 1: Capacity assessment and awareness creation. The TA will assess the 
environmental management practices in the TA areas. This will be based on earlier capacity-
building and aid assistance initiatives involving stakeholders in such areas as water quality 
management and environmental monitoring. The TA will focus on assessing the enforcement of 
industrial hazardous waste disposal measures and conduct information drives regarding their 
impacts  on  public  health.  Viable  strategies  to  disseminate  information  on  the  impacts  of 
industrial pollution on public health will be designed.  
 
12.  Output 2: Strategy and action plan formulation. This output will have two activities. 
First  is  the  preparation  of  two  strategic  urban  redevelopment  action  plans  that  will  cover 
strategic  issues  on  toxic  industrial  pollution  in  each  participating  city.  The  plans  will  be 
supplemented by policy dialogues. This will be followed by preparation of investment plans and 
policy agenda to support the comprehensive urban redevelopment strategy. Second is the 
preparation  of  two  prefeasibility  studies  to  determine  viable  hazardous  waste  treatment 
technologies for micro, small, and medium-sized industries, including clean-up of contaminated 
soil and water in affected land and water bodies and possible funding modalities.  
 
13.  Output 3: Community development and institutional strengthening. This output will 
support the implementation of the comprehensive urban redevelopment strategies for the pilot 
areas in Indonesia and the Philippines through the following activities:  
(i)  It will assess the immediate needs of the communities, alternative livelihoods, and 
target beneficiaries. 
(ii)  It  will  conduct  training  programs  on  alternative  livelihoods  and  a  training-of-
trainers  program  on  environmental  management,  in  partnership  with  local 
universities  and  research  institutions  and  based  on  the TA  project’s capacity 
needs assessment. 
(iii)  It will develop community development and livelihood support mechanisms to 
sustain alternative livelihood efforts. This will include the creation of community 
associations  or  cooperatives  to  implement  mechanisms  that  will  help  support 
livelihoods through activities such as microfinance and partnerships with private 
sector groups for job creation. 
(iv)  It will design an institutional framework and support mechanisms for integrated 
environment and urban land management. 
(v)  It  will  conduct  a  regional  workshop focused  on  the sharing  of  knowledge  on 
technologies  for  environmental  management  and  on  economically  successful 
environmental  management  projects,  particularly  those  closely  related  to  the 
issues being addressed by the TA. 
(vi)  It will prepare a guidebook on mitigation of hazardous waste for micro, small, and 
medium-sized  industries  that  will  include  options  for  financing  environmental 
management projects.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by JFPR 
and administered by ADB.11 The cost estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2015. 
ADB will be the executing agency, with the ADB Urban Development and Water Division, 
Southeast Asia Department acting as the focal, supported by the Sustainable Infrastructure 
Division  of  ADB’s  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department.  The  implementing 
agencies in the two countries will be (i) the Office of Hazardous Waste, Hazardous Substance, 
and Solid Waste Management of the Ministry of Environment in Indonesia; and (ii) the Foreign 
Assisted and Special Projects Office of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources 
in the Philippines, with the support of the department’s Environmental Management Bureau. 
The pilot locations are the municipalities of Bogor and Tegal located in the peri-urban areas of 
the Greater Jakarta Area, and the municipalities of Marilao, Meycauayan, and Obando in the 
Philippine province of Bulacan. 
 
16.  ADB will procure a total of 114 person-months of consulting services from a firm with 
international and national consultants (34 person-months for international consultants, and 80 
person-months for national consultants). In addition, an individual urban development consultant 
(national) will be recruited for 8 person-months to provide project support within ADB during 
project  implementation.  An  additional  4  person-months  of  individual  consulting  services  (2 
person-months for an international consultant, and 2 person-months for a national consultant) 
will be procured for the preparation of a guidebook on mitigation of hazardous waste for micro, 
small, and medium-sized industries. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (March 2013, as amended from time to time). TA 
proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  ADB’s  experience  in  implementing  projects  on  air  quality  and  other  fields  of 
environmental management has brought out lessons to build on for pursuing environment sector 
innovations to support inclusive growth, such as this TA. In Indonesia, the MOE is currently 
working with a nongovernment organization, the Komite Panghapusan Bensin Bertimbel, on 
information campaigns about the health impacts of lead contamination. In the Philippines, a 
possibility  exists  for  future  linkages  with  ADB’s  proposed  solid  waste  management  sector 
project. The project’s activities are expected to complement the activities and intended outputs 
of the TA and support implementation of the water quality management plan prepared by the 
DENR and the Province of Bulacan for the Meycauayan, Marilao, and Obando river system.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for the Mitigation of Hazardous Waste 
Contamination in Urban Areas: Supporting Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
